doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/2Q25 Missed Further Capacity Expansion on the Way2Q25 Missed Further Capacity Expansion on the Way_2025-08-31

passages.text: China (PRC) | Semiconductors
2Q25 Missed; Further Capacity Expansion on the Way

2Q25 big miss across PnL likely due to faster- than- expected ASP erosion of conductive SiC substrate amid continued penetration in downstream markets. EBIT/adj. NP turned loss, and slump in contract liabilities \((- 92\% / - 82\%\) YoY/QoQ) to Rmb7m also negative. Despite it, SICC has still been aggressively expanding SiC substrate capacity and migrating to \(12"\) wafer, and 2nd capacity expansion is underway. 2 fabs (Jinan & Lingang) capacity now \(>400kw\) . Maintain UNPF.

2Q25 big miss likely driven by ongoing ASP drop. SICC's 2Q25 rev dropped \(21\% /5\%\) YoY/ QoQ to Rmb386m, largely missing JEFE/cons by \(37\% /15\%\) likely due to faster- than- expected ASP decline of conductive SiC substrate amid continued penetration in downstream markets. As a result, GM slumped 11.3ppt YoY/QoQ to \(12.6\%\) , missing JEFE/cons by 16.3ppt/11.7ppt and back to similar level in mid- 2023. EBIT/adj. NP (excluding one- off items) turned negative despite effort of expense control (ope \(9\%\) YoY), vs both positive numbers from JEFE/cons. Largely shrink of contract liabilities \((- 92\% / - 82\%\) YoY/QoQ) to Rmb7m also a negative sign for near- term order pipeline.

Capacity expansion still on the way. SICC has been aggressively expanding SiC substrate capacity and migrating to \(12"\) wafer (already started mass shipment in late- 2024). Lingang fab reached its planned annual capacity of 300kw conductive substrate by mid- 2024, ahead of schedule. The 2nd capacity expansion is currently underway, bringing the combined designed capacity of 2 fabs (Jinan & Lingang) to \(>400kw\) at this point.

Maintain UNPF. We slash our rev/ NP forecast in 2025E- 27E by \(19\% /37\%\) to factor in accelerated ASP erosion of SiC substrate. Our thesis has not changed much since our last update, and we keep our bearish thesis on the whole SiC substrate industry until we can see meaningful surge demand in downstream markets or structural competition landscape changes. SICC is currently trading at 2025E/26E 14x/11x P/S, or 281x/70x P/E. We maintain UNPF at a PT of Rmb53.00 ba\$ed on end- 2025 DCF (9.0% WACC, 8.0% terminal growth rate), which implies 2025E/26E 14x/9x P/S or 231x/58x P/E and suggests 18% potential downside.
Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-US analysts on pages 11- 16 of this report. \\* Jefferies Hong Kong Limited

- Further penetration of SiC and 800V platform on EV- Higher SiC adoption in renewable inverter- Capacity expansion and ramp-up on track- Favorable design-win momentum in conductive substrate- Yield rate improvement to offset organic annual ASP erosion of substrates
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

- Annual semi-insulating substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 100kw in 2024 to 227/382kw in 2027/30- Annual conductive substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 816w in 2024 to 2,704/5,005kw in 2027/30- Semi-insulating substrate yield up from 73% in 2024 to 87%/93% in 2027/30- Conductive substrate yield up from 65% in 2024 to 83%/88% in 2027/30- PT of Rmb53.00 based on end-2025 DCF, WACC 9.0%, terminal growth rate 8.0% (2030)

- Annual semi-insulating substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 100kw in 2024 to 264/492kw in 2027/30- Annual conductive substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 816w in 2024 to 3,067/6,029kw in 2027/30- Semi-insulating substrate yield up from 73% in 2024 to 87%/93% in 2027/30- Conductive substrate yield up from 65% in 2024 to 83%/88% in 2027/30- PT of Rmb71.62 based on end-2025 DCF, WACC 9.0%, terminal growth rate 8.4% (2030)

- Annual semi-insulating substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 100kw in 2024 to 190/2734kw in 2027/30- Annual conductive substrate capacity (4" equiv) up from 816w in 2024 to 2,341/3,982kw in 2027/30- Semi-insulating substrate yield up from 73% in 2024 to 87%/93% in 2027/30- Conductive substrate yield up from 65% in 2024 to 83%/88% in 2027/30- PT of Rmb41.15 based on end-2025 DCF, WACC 9.0%, terminal growth rate 7.4% (2030)

- SICC as a SiC substrate manufacturer requires a considerable amount of electrical energy and generates wastewater, solid waste, and hazardous waste. It is important to implement energy saving measures, reduce energy consumption and environment pollution- SICC as the largest SiC substrate supplier in China has the responsibility to support the domestic supply chain, meanwhile improve its international competitiveness

- Set target of production efficiency and waste reduction for the next five years- Clarify the timeline in capacity expansion and R&D roadmap for 8" SiC substrate mass production- Key Questions for Mgt:

- What is the target for yield rate and waste reduction in 5 years?- How to balance supporting domestic supply chain and improving global competitiveness and what is your pricing strategy given the supply tightness?

- Slower-than-expected penetration of EV high voltage platform (800V)- Slower-than-expected penetration of SiC in renewable inverter- Slower-than-expected capacity expansion- Worse-than-expected design wins in conductive substrate- Slower-than-expected yield rate improvement in semi-insulating/conductive substrate- Larger-than-expected annual ASP decrease magnitude on SiC substrate

SICC engages in the research, development, production and sales of wide bandgap semiconductor substrate materials, including semi- insulating and conductive silicon carbide substrates. Its products are mainly used in 5G communication, electric vehicles and new energy.

Our price target for SICC of Rmb53.00 is based on end- 2025 DCF, with a WACC of \(9.0\%\) and a terminal growth rate of \(8.0\%\) (2030). Key risks include: 1) rapid proliferation on EV high voltage platform (800V); 2) faster- than- expected capacity expansion; 3) better- than- expected design wins in conductive substrate; 4) on- track yield rate improvement progress; 5) slower- than- expected annual ASP erosion on SiC substrate; and 6) alleviating geopolitical tension adds risks to the supply chain.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
